notes.title: Financial Statements: Structure & Linkage
notes.content: Understand the balance sheet, income statement, and cash flow statement; how accruals, matching, and closing/adjusting entries flow into retained earnings; common exam tasks include preparing statements from a trial balance and reconciling profit to operating cash flows.
keyTakeaways: Assets = Liabilities + Equity is always true; equity rolls forward via net income and dividends.
Indirect cash flow starts from net income and adjusts for non-cash & working capital.
Exam often mixes conceptual definitions with numeric preparation.

notes.title: Accounting Principles, Concepts & Conventions
notes.content: Core principles (relevance, faithful representation), assumptions (going concern, accrual), and conventions; link these to recognition and measurement questions.
keyTakeaways: Qualitative characteristics drive measurement choices.
Going concern underpins valuation; otherwise liquidation basis.
Exam frequently asks for principle vs. convention distinctions.

notes.title: Recording Process: Journal, Ledger, Trial Balance
notes.content: Double-entry, debits/credits, adjusting entries (accruals/deferrals), and trial balance → adjusted TB → statements.
keyTakeaways: Every adjusting entry affects one income statement and one balance sheet account.
Common pitfalls: prepaid vs. expense, unearned vs. revenue.
Trial balance does not guarantee error-free books.

notes.title: Revenue Recognition & Accruals
notes.content: Core idea: recognize revenue when control transfers and performance obligations are satisfied (IFRS 15); distinguish cash vs. accrual; typical questions include timing of recognition and multiple-element contracts (basic).
keyTakeaways: Accrual basis ≠ cash received.
Identify performance obligations and transaction price.
Disclosure is as important as recognition.

notes.title: Inventory Accounting (IAS 2): Costing & Valuation
notes.content: Flow assumptions (FIFO/Weighted Average), lower of cost and net realizable value (NRV), purchase and conversion costs; LIFO is prohibited under IFRS.
keyTakeaways: Write-downs to NRV require disclosure; reversals permitted if NRV recovers.
Choice of method affects COGS, gross margin, and ratios.
Exam often asks numerical FIFO/Wt. Avg. with NRV test.

notes.title: PPE & Depreciation (IAS 16) + Impairment (IAS 36)
notes.content: Initial recognition at cost, subsequent measurement (cost vs. revaluation), depreciation methods (SL/DB/SYD) and changes in estimates; impairment indicators and recoverable amount testing.
keyTakeaways: Component depreciation is required when significant parts have different lives.
Revaluation surplus goes to OCI; impairment losses to P&L (with reval nuance).
Exam mixes theory with calculations (depr., disposal, revaluation).

notes.title: Receivables & Expected Credit Losses (IFRS 9)
notes.content: Recognition of trade receivables, allowance for doubtful accounts; under IFRS 9, ECL models (12-month vs. lifetime) for financial assets.
keyTakeaways: Provisioning affects income and ratios; know direct write-off vs. allowance in exams.
Simplified approach often applies to trade receivables.
Disclosures around credit risk are examinable.

notes.title: Cash, Bank Reconciliation & Internal Control
notes.content: Cash equivalence, bank reconciliation steps, petty cash control, segregation of duties; common short question area.
keyTakeaways: Bank reconciliation explains book vs. bank timing & errors.
Controls over receipts/disbursements reduce fraud risk.
Petty cash uses imprest system.

notes.title: Cost & Managerial Accounting: CVP & Break-Even
notes.content: Cost behavior (fixed/variable/mixed), contribution margin, break-even Q = Fixed Costs/CM per unit, and margin of safety; typical exam numericals.
keyTakeaways: Use contribution format for quick what-if analysis.
Operating leverage magnifies profit sensitivity.
CVP assumes linearity within relevant range.

notes.title: Job Order vs. Process Costing
notes.content: When to use each system; computing unit costs, equivalent units (FIFO/WA), overhead allocation and under/over-applied overhead.
keyTakeaways: Job order: heterogeneous, process: homogeneous continuous flow.
Be fluent with equivalent units in process costing.
Predetermined OH rate = Est. OH / Est. allocation base.

notes.title: Budgeting & Variance Analysis
notes.content: Master, flexible, and cash budgets; materials, labor, and overhead variances; common short numericals.
keyTakeaways: Flexible budgets separate activity and spending variances.
Standard costing ties into performance evaluation.
Cash budget links operations to financing needs.

notes.title: Audit Fundamentals: Assertions & Evidence
notes.content: Financial statement assertions (existence, completeness, rights/obligations, accuracy/valuation, presentation), audit procedures and evidence reliability hierarchy.
keyTakeaways: Design procedures to test specific assertions.
External confirmations/inspection > inquiry for reliability.
Documentation must enable an experienced auditor to understand work performed.

notes.title: Risk Assessment (ISA 315) & Responses (ISA 330)
notes.content: Identify and assess risks of material misstatement via understanding the entity, environment, and internal control; determine significant risks and tailor responses.
keyTakeaways: Spectrum of inherent risk helps flag significant risks.
Link assessed risks to nature/timing/extent of tests.
Controls testing vs. substantive procedures trade-off.

notes.title: Materiality (ISA 320) & Audit Opinion
notes.content: Set overall and performance materiality; accumulate misstatements; evaluate effect on the opinion (unmodified, qualified, adverse, disclaimer).
keyTakeaways: Performance materiality < overall materiality to absorb errors.
Materiality is both quantitative and qualitative.
Clear linkage from misstatements to opinion type.

notes.title: ISA for Less Complex Entities (ISA for LCE)
notes.content: A standalone standard tailored for audits of less complex entities, effective for audits beginning on or after 15 Dec 2025 (jurisdictional adoption dependent).
keyTakeaways: Same level of reasonable assurance as ISAs.
Streamlined requirements for LCEs.
Know scope and eligibility concepts.

notes.title: IFRS Landscape & Access
notes.content: IFRS Accounting Standards issued by the IASB under IFRS Foundation; for CSS, know major IAS/IFRS, terminology, and where to find official materials.
keyTakeaways: IFRS is principle-based; many exams test conceptual application.
Official texts live on IFRS.org; summaries elsewhere are secondary.
Pakistan's listed companies report under IFRS as adopted locally.

notes.title: Corporate Governance (Pakistan) for Auditing & Reporting
notes.content: SECP's Listed Companies Code of Corporate Governance sets board composition, audit committee, auditor rotation, and disclosure requirements—often examinable in Paper II essays.
keyTakeaways: Know board independence, audit committee roles, internal audit mandate.
Understand comply-or-explain and enforcement context.
Governance links to audit risk and reporting quality.

notes.title: Taxation (Pakistan): Income Tax Ordinance 2001
notes.content: Understand charge of tax, scope, residential status, heads of income, allowable deductions, credits, and computation framework; CSS numericals commonly test salary and business income.
keyTakeaways: Use the latest amended text for thresholds and rates.
Classify income heads correctly and apply adjustments.
Keep an eye on exemptions/credits and recent Finance Acts.

notes.title: Sales Tax & Withholding Overview (Pakistan)
notes.content: At a high level, understand sales tax framework and common withholding categories relevant to business transactions—useful for conceptual CSS questions.
keyTakeaways: Separate direct (income) vs indirect (sales) tax treatment.
Withholding regimes affect cash flows and compliance.
Always reference current SROs/Finance Acts.

notes.title: Financial Ratios & Statement Analysis
notes.content: Liquidity, solvency, activity/turnover, profitability, and market ratios; interpretation, cross-sectional vs. time-series.
keyTakeaways: Context matters: compare to peers and industry.
DuPont decomposes ROE into margin × turnover × leverage.
Exam may give raw statements and ask for ratio set + commentary.

notes.title: Time Value of Money & Capital Budgeting
notes.content: Present/future value, annuities; project appraisal via NPV, IRR, payback; CSS numericals commonly appear here.
keyTakeaways: NPV is value-additive and preferred to IRR when conflicting.
Use appropriate discount rate (WACC or project-specific).
Beware non-conventional cash flows (multiple IRRs).

notes.title: Bonds & Long-Term Liabilities
notes.content: Issuance at discount/premium, effective interest amortization, covenant basics, and IFRS presentation.
keyTakeaways: Issue price = PV of coupons + PV of principal at market yield.
Carrying amount moves toward face over time.
Disclosures on terms and covenants are examinable.

notes.title: FPSC CSS—Syllabus, Paper I & II Patterns
notes.content: Use the official FPSC syllabus and recent papers to align prep: Paper-I heavy on financial accounting & cost; Paper-II on auditing, governance, and business finance.
keyTakeaways: Practice past questions on statement prep, costing, and audit essays.
Mix objective MCQs drills with full-length structured responses.
Quote standards/regulations precisely in Paper-II.

notes.title: High-Yield Video Channels (CSS-friendly curation)
notes.content: Use concise, exam-oriented channels for fast revision on fundamentals, IFRS summaries, and numericals.
keyTakeaways: Prioritize structured playlists over random videos.
Cross-check any YouTube shortcuts with IFRS/IAASB originals.
Build topic-wise watchlists matching FPSC syllabus.
